question: A simple pendulum has a period of 2 seconds on Earth. If the pendulum is taken to the Moon, where the acceleration due to gravity is about 1/6 that of Earth, what will be the new period of the pendulum?
solution:
The period of a simple pendulum is given by the formula T = 2π√(L/g), where L is the length of the pendulum and g is the acceleration due to gravity. If g is reduced to 1/6 of its value on Earth, the new period can be calculated as follows:

T_moon = 2π√(L/(g_earth/6))
T_moon = 2π√(6L/g_earth)
T_moon = √6 * 2π√(L/g_earth)
T_moon = √6 * T_earth

Since the period on Earth is 2 seconds, the period on the Moon will be:

T_moon = √6 * 2 s ≈ 4.90 s

Therefore, the new period of the pendulum on the Moon will be approximately 4.90 seconds.
